This book survived and was published by Wandesford's great-grandson: Book of Instructions, Written by Sir Christr. Wandesforde […], ed. Thomas Comber (Cambridge: J. Archdeacon, 1777).
When Christopher Wandesford's father died in 1612, he was left with an estate burdened with debts.
'Probate copies of the will of Lord Deputy Christopher Wandesforde; Nos. 196 & 196A, 2 Oct 1640; copies made Apr 1647 & Dec 1659', Ms 35,458 (1), National Library of Ireland, Dublin.

England had experienced civil war fighting between 1639-53. The Cromwellian 'settlement' of Ireland, which began with a military invasion in 1649, essentially meant the country was under military rule for much of the 1650s, under a succession of Lord Deputies (Henry Ireton, Charles Fleetwood and Henry Cromwell). See John Cunningham, 'Oliver Cromwell and the ‘Cromwellian’ Settlement of Ireland', The Historical Journal 53, no. 4 (2010): 919–37.

After the Irish rebellion of 1641, Ireland was effectively under military rule until 1660: first, it was under control of the Catholic confederacy (1642-49) and was then reconquered by Cromwell during the Protectorate (1649–60). See Pádraig Lenihan, Consolidating Conquest: Ireland 1603-1727 (Oxford: Routledge, 2014), chaps. 6 and 7.

Robert Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652 with a case against Christopher Wandesford, Thornton's brother: 'Nettleton v. C. Wandesford et al.', C 5/379/135, TNA, London. In 1653 and later in 1656 Nettleton was in dispute with Thornton's uncle William Wandesford: 'Nettleton v. W. Wandesford', C 5/402/105, TNA, London; 'Nettleton v. Wandesford', C 22/811/15, TNA, London.
Thornton does not mention this particular deliverance in any of her other books.
Thornton notes four escapes from fire in her books: Book 1, 11, 14, and Book 2, 176, 223.
See Raymond A. Anselment, ‘Smallpox in Seventeenth-Century English Literature: Reality and the Metamorphosis of Wit’, Medical History 33, no. 1 (1989): 72–95.

Thornton lived in Ireland c. 1633-41. During this time she experienced being in a coach that overturned (Book 1, 287–8), a fall from being swung by her arms (Book 1, 289–90), a near-shipwreck on the way back from England (Book 1, 15–16), and the breaking out of the Irish rebellion (Book 1, 66–7).

The Irish Rebellion, which broke out on 23 October 1641, was an uprising of Catholics in Ireland against anti-Catholic discrimination, English colonialism and the use of plantations. See Pádraig Lenihan, Consolidating Conquest : Ireland 1603–1727 (Oxford: Routledge, 2014), chap. 5.

The allegations of the killing of Protestants, including children, by Catholics during the Dublin rebellion was at the centre of anti-Catholic mythology around the riots. See Naomi McAreavey, 'Children's Experiences of Violence during the Irish Rebellion of 1641', Parergon 38, no. 2 (2021): 71–103.

The Irish Rebellion which broke out in Dublin in October 1641 was an uprising of Catholics in Ireland against anti-Catholic discrimination, English colonialism and the use of plantations. See Pádraig Lenihan, Consolidating Conquest: Ireland 1603–1727 (Oxford: Routledge, 2014), chap. 5.
See Book 1, 62–6.

Thornton's account of Owen Connelly's discovery of the plot in 1641 adds dramatic flourishes that are not present in his 1641 deposition. 'Information of Owen Connallie', 22/10/1641, 1641 Depositions, MS 809, Trinity College Dublin, ff. 13r–14v, http://1641.tcd.ie/index.php/deposition/?depID=809013r003.

The Irish Rebellion which broke out in Dublin in October 1641 was an uprising of Catholics in Ireland against anti-Catholic discrimination, English colonialism and the use of plantations. See Pádraig Lenihan, Consolidating Conquest: Ireland 1603–1727 (Oxford: Routledge, 2014), chap. 5.

The Irish Rebellion, which broke out on 23 October 1641, was an uprising of Catholics in Ireland against anti-Catholic discrimination, English colonialism and the use of plantations. See Pádraig Lenihan, Consolidating Conquest : Ireland 1603–1727 (Oxford: Routledge, 2014), chap. 5.
Thornton describes the various dangers and frights caused by the rebels over 14 days which led up to the outbreak of illness in Book 1, 66.
See Raymond A. Anselment, ‘Smallpox in Seventeenth-Century English Literature: Reality and the Metamorphosis of Wit’, Medical History 33, no. 1 (1989): 72–95.

Chester was a royalist garrison in 1644, but was subject to repeated parliamentarian attacks and sieges under Brereton in 1644–5. In September 1645 the mayor's house was captured by parliamentarian forces and taken over by Brereton as his headquarters. See C. P. Lewis and A. T. Thacker, A History of the County of Chester: Volume 5 Part 1 (London: Victoria County History, 2003), 117–8.
On the use of grenades in the civil war, see Barbara Donagan, War in England 1642–1649 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008), 89–90.

This does not refer to the well-known siege of Chester in 1644 but to William Brereton's first unsuccessful attack on the city in July 1643. See C. P. Lewis and A. T. Thacker, A History of the County of Chester: Volume 5 Part 1 (London: Victoria County History, 2003), 117. On the use of grenades in the civil war, see Barbara Donagan, War in England 1642-1649 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008), 89–90.

The Richmond parish registers list 574 infected people among the burials between the end of March and September 1645. This may or may not refer solely to plague infections but the number is certainly high. Jane Hatcher, The History of Richmond, North Yorkshire, From Earliest Times to the Year 2000 (Pickering: Blackthorn, 2000), 108.

p.hi: Scottish soldiers had been free quartered at Hipswell Hall since at least 1644. In

, pages 84-5, Thornton says the family finally arrived there after November 1644 to find quartered soldiers on the property. They were led by one Captain Robert Innes, who Thornton claims tried to force her into marriage. We cannot date the return of the troop to Scotland precisely, but they fought in the attack on Newark in 1646, before disbanding completely in February 1647. Innes was certainly back in Scotland by May 1648. Whether or not the troop was quartered at Alice Wandesford's property the entire time is not known. See E. M. Furgol,
A Regimental History of the Covenanting Armies

note.p: The age of first communion in the Church of England was implied as 14 in Grindal's injunctions of 1571, but this was a very rough guide. It is not outside usual norms that Thornton first took communion at 16, especially with the considerable upheaval her family had undergone in 1640-41. See Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), 33–8.

The concept that human life fell into stages was common. Here, Thornton describes a schema of three – in line with Aristostle's concept of youth, maturity and old age. See Cordelia Beattie, ‘The Life Cycle: The Ages of Medieval Women’, in A Cultural History of Women: In the Middle Ages, ed. Kim M. Phillips (London: Bloomsbury, 2013), 16-18.

In early modern England, fatherless children were legally described as orphans. See Charles Carlton, 'Changing Jurisdictions in 16th and 17th Century England: The Relationship between the Courts of Orphans and Chancery', The American Journal of Legal History 18, no. 2 (1974): 124–36.
Book 1, 79.
This was the first English Civil War, 1642–6. See J. S. Morrill, The Nature of the English Revolution (Oxford: Routledge, 2013), chap. 1.

Marston Moor was about seven miles west of York. On this battle, a decisive parliamentarian victory which took place on 2 July 1644 at Hessom (later Marston) Moor, see Michael Braddick, God's fury, England's fire: a new history of the English Civil Wars (London: Penguin, 2009), chap. 11.

York was a royalist stronghold, under siege by parliamentarians for several months in early 1644, when – after the royalist defeat at Marston Moor on 2 July – it became a parliamentarian garrison. See P. M. Tillott, A History of the County of York: The City of York (London: Victoria County History, 1961), 190.
On the metaphor of Apollo's arrow as a cause of plague, see Sheila Barker, 'Poussin, Plague, and Early Modern Medicine', The Art Bulletin 86, no. 4 (2004): 659–89.

The Richmond parish registers list 574 infected people among the burials between the end of March and September 1645. This may or may not refer solely to plague infections but the number is certainly high. Jane Hatcher, The History of Richmond, North Yorkshire, From Earliest Times to the Year 2000 (Pickering: Blackthorn, 2000), 108.

p.hi: The period of 1647–50 saw a famine across England, caused by a mix of economic and constitutional crises. See Steve Hindle, 'Dearth and the English Revolution: The Harvest Crisis of 1647–50',

note.p: Thornton was born on 13 February 1626 and, when she married in December 1651, she was two months short of her 26th birthday.

When William Thornton wrote to Alice Wandesford before his marriage to her daughter, he explained that his stepfather, Geoffrey Gates, would not join in a 'fine' guaranteeing that his mother’s jointure could be used as stipulated in the draft marriage agreement; as a married woman, Elizabeth Gates could not make a legally binding agreement regarding this land. 'Mr Thornton to Lady Wandesford, 11 November 1651', reproduced in The Autobiography of Mrs. Alice Thornton of East Newton, Co. York, ed. Charles Jackson, Surtees Society 62 (Durham: Andrews & Co., 1875), 287–8.

When William Thornton wrote to Alice Wandesford before his marriage to her daughter, he explained that his stepfather, Geoffrey Gates, would not join in a 'fine' guaranteeing that his mother’s jointure could be used as stipulated in the draft marriage agreement; as a married woman, Elizabeth Gates could not make a legally binding agreement regarding this land. 'Mr Thornton to Lady Wandesford, 11 November 1651', reproduced in The Autobiography of Mrs. Alice Thornton of East Newton, Co. York, ed. Charles Jackson, Surtees Society 62 (Durham: Andrews & Co., 1875), 287–8.

William Thornton wrote to Alice Wandesford on 7 August 1651 and again on 11 November 1651; the latter as the matter of his father-in-law agreeing to his mother’s use of jointure lands was still not resolved. 'William Thornton to Lady Wandesford, 7 August 1651' and 'William Thornton to Lady Wandesford, 11 November 1651', reproduced in The Autobiography of Mrs. Alice Thornton of East Newton, Co. York, ed. Charles Jackson, Surtees Society 62 (Durham: Andrews & Co., 1875), 286, 287–8.

For Thornton’s marriage settlement, see Book 1, 120-3. On marriage settlements more generally, see Amy Louise Erickson, 'Common Law versus Common Practice: The Use of Marriage Settlements in Early Modern England', The Economic History Review 43, no. 1 (1990): 21–39.

Alice and William Thornton married at her mother's home, Hipswell Hall (Book 1, 124). The changes in marriage laws in the 1640s and 1650s, which stipulated that only a Justice of the Peace could marry couples and that church weddings were not permissible, led to confusion. Marriages took place in both church and secular environments during this time and afterwards, and might be conducted by a priest or a Justice of the Peace. See Christopher Durston, The Family in the English Revolution (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1989), chap. 4.
Thornton perhaps misremembered what time she became ill: 2pm or supper time.

Changes to humoural balance and complexions was seen as a cause of violent purging in early modern medicine. See Andrew Wear, 'Puritan Perceptions of Illness in Seventeenth Century England', in Patients and Practitioners: Lay Perceptions of Medicine in Pre-Industrial Society ed. Roy Porter (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1986): 55–100.

Sarah and Rebecca, the first two matriarchs of the Old Testament. See Carol Meyers, ‘Rebekah: Bible’, in Shalvi/Hyman Encyclopedia of Jewish Women, 23 June 2021, <https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/rebekah-bible> and Tikva Frymer-Kensky, ‘Sarah/Sarai:Bible’, in Shalvi/Hyman Encyclopedia of Jewish Women, 31 December 1999, <https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/sarahsarai-bible>.

The 1650s saw extremes of weather with several harsh winters, however, winter 1651–2 is noted as having been especially mild with a hot spring and summer following, leading to a drought. 'Weather in History 1650 to 1699 AD', Weatherweb, https://premium.weatherweb.net/weather-in-history-1650-to-1699-ad/.

The total solar eclipse of 1652 was known for years afterwards as 'Black Monday'. See William E. Burns, '“The Terriblest Eclipse That Hath Been Seen in Our Days”: Black Monday and the Debate on Astrology during the Interregnum' in Rethinking the Scientific Revolution ed. Margaret J. Osler (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000), 137–52. On Thornton's recounting of the eclipse see Joanne Edge, 'Black Monday: The Solar Eclipse of 1652', Alice Thornton’s Books (blog), https://thornton.kdl.kcl.ac.uk/posts/blog/2022-10-25-black-monday-solar-eclipse-1652.

Thornton's first child, an unnamed daughter, was born on 27 August 1652 and died the same day. In March 1652, then, she was about four months pregnant, and probably not that 'big' with child. See Book 1, 129.

Presumably Thornton looked at the eclipse in water because it was common knowledge that looking directly upon it could cause blindness. Several popular works of astrology included guidance about how to do this safely, e.g. Edward Pond, An Almanack for the year of our Lord God 1652 (Cambridge: the printers to the University, 1652), sig. C1v.

Thornton's reference to the 'bridegroom of the soul', from the Song of Songs, relates to Christian bridal theology: the notion of 'marriage to Jesus'. On this practice, see Rabia Gregory, Marrying Jesus in medieval and early modern northern Europe: popular culture and religious reform (London: Routledge, 2016), 28.

Medical literature advised against letting blood in pregnant women unless absolutely necessary, because this could cause miscarriage. See, e.g., Nicholas Culpeper, Culpeper's directory for midwives: or, A guide for women (London: Peter Cole, 1662), 159.
Thornton was likely sitting to prepare food, sewing or carrying out other domestic duties.

Medical literature advised against letting blood in pregnant women unless absolutely necessary, because this could cause miscarriage. See, e.g., Nicholas Culpeper, Culpeper's directory for midwives: or, A guide for women (London: Peter Cole, 1662), 159.

Ralph and Mary Crathorne, William's sister and brother-in-law, lived at Crathorne. William Thornton's uncle, Richard Darley, lived at Buttercrambe. William's sister Anne and brother-in-law Philip Langdale lived at Langthorpe Hall, Ellerby, in the East Riding, not far from Beverley and Hull. And as Thornton notes, William’s mother and stepfather were living at Burn Park at this time, just outside Hull.

Bloodletting manuals often included regimens for patients after bloodletting, which involved careful management of diet and rest, and possibly further bloodletting, which is why the Thorntons would not have been able to leave for two days after the procedure. See e.g. Nicholas Gyer, The English phlebotomy […] (London: Andrew Mansell, 1592), 265–6.
According to Thornton, their house at East Newton was rebuilt during their marriage, from about 1656–62.

On corrupted blood in early modern medicine see Michael Stolberg, '''You have no good blood in your body": Oral communication in sixteenth-century physicians' medical practice', Medical History 59:1 (2015): 63–82.
See Book 1, 126–9.

I.e., a stillbirth. On this meaning, see Jennifer Evans, ‘“It Bringeth Them into Dangerous Perill”: Management of and Recovery after Miscarriage in Early Modern England, c.1600–1750', Historical Research 96, no. 271 (2023): 17.
This implies an excess of humours in the womb.

Thornton's first child, an unnamed daughter, was born and died on 27th August 1652. She had been very ill since 6th August and believed her miscarriage to have been caused by walking down a steep cliff. See Book 1, 126–9.
I.e., pregnant.
This usually meant the woman was about five months pregnant, although in this case Thornton says she was only about 11 or 12 weeks pregnant. .
This usually meant the woman was about five months pregnant, although in this case Thornton says she was only about 11 or 12 weeks pregnant.
Thornton fell ill during her first pregnancy, which she thought resulted in her newborn child dying almost as soon as she was born. See Book 1, 126–9.

Medical literature advised against letting blood in pregnant women unless absolutely necessary, because this could cause miscarriage. See, e.g., Nicholas Culpeper, Culpeper's directory for midwives: or, A guide for women (London: Peter Cole, 1662), 159.

During pregnancy, women were thought to retain the blood they would normally expel during menstruation to nourish the foetus. It would then be expelled postpartum or made into breastmilk. Blood was a hot and moist humour and so this excess of blood in the body was seen to cause greater heat in their bodies. See Wendy D. Churchill, Female Patients in Early Modern Britain Gender, Diagnosis, and Treatment (London: Routledge, 2016), 156.

I.e., a stillbirth. On this meaning, see Jennifer Evans, ‘“It Bringeth Them into Dangerous Perill”: Management of and Recovery after Miscarriage in Early Modern England, c.1600–1750', Historical Research 96, no. 271 (2023): 17.

Bloodletting was a standard treatment in the premodern period, thought to rid the body of an excess of blood and restore balance. See Michael Stolberg, Learned Physicians and Everyday Medical Practice in the Renaissance (Munich: De Gruyter Oldenbourg, 2021), 189–200.

While Thornton saw it as her Christian duty to breastfeed her own children, she did on occasion employ a wet-nurse. On the maternal duty to breastfeed in seventeenth-century England see Rachel Trubowitz, ‘“Nourish-Milke”: Breast-Feeding and the Crisis of Englishness, 1600-1660’, The Journal of English and Germanic Philology 99, no. 1 (2000): 29–49.

Rickets may not refer here to a vitamin D deficiency, although rickets was recorded as a cause of death in the seventeenth century. See Gill Newton, 'Diagnosing Rickets in Early Modern England: Statistical Evidence and Social Response', Social History of Medicine, 35:2 (2022): 566–88.

Wet-nurses were advised to abstain from sexual intercourse for fear of becoming pregnant and polluting their milk. See Alexandra Shepard, ‘The Pleasures and Pains of Breastfeeding in England c.1600–c.1800’, in Suffering and Happiness in England 1550–1850: Narratives and Representations. A Collection to Honour Paul Slack, ed. Michael J. Braddick and Joanne Innes (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017), 236.

Rickets may not refer here to a vitamin D deficiency, although rickets was recorded as a cause of death in the seventeenth century. See Gill Newton, 'Diagnosing Rickets in Early Modern England: Statistical Evidence and Social Response', Social History of Medicine, 35:2 (2022): 566–88.

On the maternal duty to breastfeed in seventeenth-century England see Rachel Trubowitz, ''Nourish-Milke': Breast-Feeding and the Crisis of Englishness, 1600–1660', The Journal of English and Germanic Philology 99, no. 1 (2000): 29–49.

Seventeenth-century physicians advised that babies were weaned in their second year, at around the age of 18 months. See Marylynn Salmon, ‘The Cultural Significance of Breastfeeding and Infant Care in Early Modern England and America’, Journal of Social History 28, no. 2 (1994): 256.

In the early modern period, bedrooms were most often decorated in red, green or blue. Blue had strong associations with feelings of purity, sincerity, love and temperance. See Sasha Handley, Sleep in Early Modern England (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), 138.

On the maternal duty to breastfeed in seventeenth-century England see Rachel Trubowitz, ‘“Nourish-Milke”: Breast-Feeding and the Crisis of Englishness, 1600–1660’, The Journal of English and Germanic Philology 99, no. 1 (2000): 29–49.

Thornton implies that she stopped breastfeeding in order to allow Daphne Lightfoot to continue while the baby was weaned onto solid food. On the maternal duty to breastfeed in seventeenth-century England see Rachel Trubowitz, '"Nourish-Milke": Breast-Feeding and the Crisis of Englishness, 1600–1660', The Journal of English and Germanic Philology 99, no. 1 (2000): 29–49.

Wet-nurses were advised to abstain from sexual intercourse for fear of becoming pregnant and polluting their milk. See Alexandra Shepard, ‘The Pleasures and Pains of Breastfeeding in England c.1600–c.1800’, in Suffering and Happiness in England 1550–1850: Narratives and Representations. A Collection to Honour Paul Slack, ed. Michael J. Braddick and Joanne Innes (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017), 236.
See Book 1, 142–7.
I.e., her midwife was good, partly because she had two 'great forebears' (a mother and grandmother) who were also known as skilled midwives.

Rickets may not refer here to a vitamin D deficiency, although rickets was recorded as a cause of death in the seventeenth century. See Gill Newton, 'Diagnosing Rickets in Early Modern England: Statistical Evidence and Social Response', Social History of Medicine, 35:2 (May 2022): 566–588.

A wet nurse's character needed to be good, otherwise it was thought the milk would pass on bad traits or illnesses to the baby she was breastfeeding. See Alexandra Shepard, 'The Pleasures and Pains of Breastfeeding in England c.1600–c.1800', in Suffering and Happiness in England 1550-1850: Narratives and Representations: A Collection to Honour Paul Slack, ed. Michael J. Braddick and Joanne Innes (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017), 236.
St Mungo's Well was considered especially effective for treating rickets, as recommended by the Thorntons' physician. See Robert Wittie, Scarborough Spaw […] (London: Charles Tyus, 1660), 141–3.

It was usual for midwives to discern the position of a baby in the womb by observing external signs. For example, one manual stated that a midwife should look at a woman's belly when she first went into labour to work out the baby's position in the womb: John Pechey, The compleat midwife's practice […] (London: H. Rhodes, 1698), 111.

Bloodletting was a standard treatment in the premodern period, thought to rid the body of an excess of blood and restore balance. See Michael Stolberg, Learned Physicians and Everyday Medical Practice in the Renaissance (Munich: De Gruyter Oldenbourg, 2021), 189–200.

On birth figures, which were printed early modern visual guides to the different positions of foetuses in the womb, see Rebecca Whiteley, Birth Figures: Early Modern Prints and the Pregnant Body (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 2023), 21–50.
On the use of birthing stools in early modern England see Amanda Carson Banks, Birth Chairs, Midwives, and Medicine (Jackson: University Press of Mississippi, 1999), 1–32.
I.e., the baby was born breech. Jane Sharp discusses how to deal with breech births in her seventeenth-century midwifery manual. Jane Sharp, The Midwives Book […] (London: Simon Miller, 1671), 191–2.

Thornton's postpartum knee injury may be explained by early modern birthing practices. Describing how a midwife might position a woman in labour, Jane Sharp instructed that knees should be ‘wide open asunder’: Jane Sharp, The Midwives Book, or, The Whole Art of Midwifry Discovered […] (London: printed for Simon Miller, 1671), 204.
Thornton placed meditations and prayers on the births of her children Elizabeth and Katherine in Book 1, pages 136–47.

The waters at Scarborough Spa, a healing remedy advised by the family physician, who wrote a treatise on the virtues of this spa, first published in 1660: Robert Wittie, Scarbrough Spaw […] (London: Charles Tyus, 1660).
See Book 1, 154-5.

November 1659 was when the surviving leaders of the Long Parliament (the so-called 'Presbyterian Knot') agreed on the Restoration of Charles II. Ronald Hutton, The Restoration: A Political and Religious History of England and Wales, 1658–1667 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1993), 105. See also Book 1, 155–8.
See Book 1, 166–77.

p.hi: Christopher Wandesford submitted a bill to Chancery in 1659 against Richard Darley, William Thornton and Alice Thornton, which touches on disputes about the Wandesford estate. 'Wandesford v. Darley, William Thornton, Alice Thornton et al. 1659', C 10/57/305, TNA, London. [this isn’t really about the will]

note.p: In Alice Wandesford's will the residue of goods not allocated was given to Thornton and her children. See 'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Lord Deputy Wandesford — 10th January 1658. Proved at London 19th July 1660', Hardy Bertram McCall, The Story of the Family of Wandesforde of Kirklington & Castlecomer […] (London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton & co., 1904), 357–8; ‘The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Hipswell, Yorkshire’, July 1660, PROB 11/298/634, TNA, Kew.
'Friends' here is used to mean 'kin'. [means the Thorntons here; do we usually give the IED def?]
John Frescheville and Francis Darley are named executors in Alice Wandesford's will.
Used here to mean the Ryedale area.

Alice Wandesford's will opens with a plea to her appointed executors to 'shew their special love and care to my daughter Alice Thorneton, wife of William Thorneton of East Newton, and her children': 'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Lord Deputy Wandesford — 10th January 1658. Proved at London 19th July 1660', Hardy Bertram McCall, The Story of the Family of Wandesforde of Kirklington & Castlecomer […] (London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton & co., 1904), 357-8. See also ‘The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford’, 10 January 1658, PROB 11/298/624, TNA, London.
The will was proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury since Alice Wandesford held lands in multiple jurisdictions.

The realty (i.e., land assets) of intestates in the seventeenth century passed directly to their heirs, and personalty (i.e., movable goods) to spouses. See Roger Kerridge, 'Intestate Succession in England and Wales', in Comparative Succession Law: Volume II: Intestate Succession, ed. Kenneth Reid, Marius de Waal, and Reinhard Zimmermann (Oxford University Press, 2015), 325.

'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Lord Deputy Wandesford — 10th January 1658. Proved at London 19th July 1660', Hardy Bertram McCall, The Story of the Family of Wandesforde of Kirklington & Castlecomer […] (London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton & co., 1904), 357-8; ‘The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford’, 10 January 1658, PROB 11/298/624, TNA, London.
According to Thornton, Sir John Lowther, Christopher's father-in-law, encouraged Christopher to take out a lawsuit against the Thorntons over the Wandesford estates in Ireland. See Book 2, 135.

William Thornton was involved in a Chancery dispute with Robert Nettleton, from at least 1661, which stemmed from his involvement in the administration of Christopher Wandesford’s will: 'Thornton v. R. Nettleton et al.', C 5/633/108, TNA, London. Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652.

The practicalities of daily life meant that ways had to be found around coverture, which meant that a husband took possession of all his wife's property. The 'law of necessities' (or ‘of agency’), for example, allowed married women to make contracts 'for necessities'. See Joanne Bailey, ‘Favoured or Oppressed? Married Women, Property and “Coverture” in England, 1660–1800’, Continuity and Change 17 (2002), 356–61.
This is a slip; Alice Wandesford died in 1659, so 30 years later would be 1689, not 1680.
There is a gap left here, which suggests Thornton intended to return at a later date to fill in the final amount.

Women who had given birth were advised to stay in bed for at least one month to help with their physical recovery. See Leah Astbury, 'Being Well, Looking Ill: Childbirth and the Return to Health in Seventeenth-Century England', Social History of Medicine 30, no. 3 (2017): 500–19.

Christopher Wandesford submitted a bill to Chancery in 1659 against Richard Darley, William Thornton and Alice Thornton, which touches on earlier disputes about the Wandesford estate. 'Wandesford v. Darley, William Thornton, Alice Thornton et al. 1659', C 10/57/305, TNA, London.
With no space remaining at the bottom of the manuscript page, this last line/clause was written vertically in the left margin (see image).
On women and dreams in early modern England see Patricia Crawford, ‘Women’s Dreams in Early Modern England’, History Workshop Journal no. 49 (2000): 129–41.

Women who had given birth were advised to stay in bed for at least one month to help with their physical recovery. See Leah Astbury, 'Being Well, Looking Ill: Childbirth and the Return to Health in Seventeenth-Century England', Social History of Medicine 30, no. 3 (2017): 500–19.

For reformed protestants. the sacrament of baptism represented ‘the seal of the Holy Spirit on a Christian’. See Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), 330.

Blessing of the breasts was the the production of breastmilk and blessing of the womb indicated a reasonable flow of post-partum blood. See Sara Read, Menstruation and the Female Body in Early Modern England (London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2013), 155.

Gascon's or Gascoigne's Powder was a popular household remedy from the mid-seventeenth century through to the nineteenth. See John K. Crellin, 'Gascoigne's powder: A British prescription and home medicine, 1600s to early 1900s', Pharmaceutical Historian 49, no. 1 (2019): 1–15.

The use of cordials as medicine in the early modern period is discussed in Elaine Leong, 'Making Medicines in the Early Modern Household', Bulletin of the History of Medicine 82, no. 1 (2008): 145–68.
See Raymond A. Anselment, ‘Smallpox in Seventeenth-Century English Literature: Reality and the Metamorphosis of Wit’, Medical History 33, no. 1 (1989): 72–95.

The Commonwealth halfpenny, in circulation from 1649-60, was the smallest coin of the period, with a diameter of 9.21mm. This suggests that William's spots had a diameter of about 1cm. 'Coin: BUC-688073', Portable Antiquities Scheme, https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/163228, accessed 30 November 2023.

Cotton and linen garments seem to have been preferred for nightwear in the seventeenth century but it is not possible to know if these would have been colder or warmer than William's day clothes. See Sasha Handley, Sleep in Early Modern England (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), 53.

The use of cordials as medicine in the early modern period is discussed throughout Elaine Leong, ‘Making Medicines in the Early Modern Household’, Bulletin of the History of Medicine 82, no. 1 (2008): 145–68.
See Book 1, 179.
Thornton's first child, a girl, died half an hour after her birth on 27 August 1652. See Book 1, 129.

Charles II's coronation actually took place on 23 April 1661. Thornton here is noting his date of restoration. See Cordelia Beattie, 'Alice Thornton on the Coronation of Charles II: The North Remembers (sort of)', Alice Thornton's Books, 23 April 2023, https://thornton.kdl.kcl.ac.uk/posts/blog/2023-04-23-coronation-charles-II/.
See Book 1, 180-1.
Used here to mean the Richmondshire area.
Thornton had moved from Richmondshire, where she was born and lived for most of her adult life, to Ryedale, which she viewed as being very different parts of Yorkshire.

Charles II's coronation actually took place on 23rd April 1661. Thornton here is noting his date of restoration. See Cordelia Beattie, 'Alice Thornton on the Coronation of Charles II: The North Remembers (sort of)', Alice Thornton's Books, 23 April 2023, https://thornton.kdl.kcl.ac.uk/posts/blog/2023-04-23-coronation-charles-II/.

On the medical uses of amber in the early modern period see Rachel King, 'Objective Thinking: Early Modern Objects in Amber with Curative, Preservative and Medical Functions', in Amber in the History of Medicine: Proceedings of the International Conference ed. C. Duffin, I. Polyakova & T. Surova (Kaliningrad: Kaliningrad Regional Amber Museum, 2016), 80–94.
On the medicinal uses of peony seeds in the early modern period see Ashley Buchanan, 'The Power of Peony', The Recipes Project, May 12, 2022, https://recipes.hypotheses.org/18635.

Rickets may not refer here to a vitamin D deficiency, although rickets was recorded as a cause of death in the seventeenth century. See Gill Newton, 'Diagnosing Rickets in Early Modern England: Statistical Evidence and Social Response', Social History of Medicine, 35:2 (May 2022): 566–88.

Thornton's account here gives us a more accurate date for the building (c.1656–62) than that by Pevsner (1620-30): Jane Grenville and Nikolaus Pevsner, Yorkshire: The North Riding (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2023), 261.

Leeches were one method used to let blood in early modern England, along with lancets and scarification. See Hannah Newton, Misery to Mirth: Recovery from Illness in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2018), 55.

Thornton uses Lady Day dating here, which began the year on 25 March. 1661 should read 1662: Thornton goes on to say she was pregnant but she had no child (or reported miscarriage) in 1661, whereas her son, Robert, was born in September 1662; Shrove Tuesday fell on 11 February in 1662, as Easter Sunday fell on 30 March.

Pew-rents were introduced in the early seventeenth century as a way of boosting church income. It meant that seating came in order of social precedence. See Christopher Marsh, ''Common Prayer' in England 1560-1640: The View from the Pew', Past & Present, no. 171 (2001): 66–94.

Humoural theory held that extremes of temperature, both cold and hot, would provoke an excess of humours and cause illness. See Mary Lindemann, Medicine and Society in Early Modern Europe, 2nd edition (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2010), 19.
Used here to mean the Richmondshire area.

Thornton uses Lady Day dating here, which began the year on 25 March. 1661 should read 1662: Thornton goes on to say she was pregnant but she had no child (or reported miscarriage) in 1661, whereas her son, Robert, was born in September 1662.

Bloodletting was a standard treatment in the premodern period, thought to rid the body of an excess of blood and restore balance. See Michael Stolberg, Learned Physicians and Everyday Medical Practice in the Renaissance (Munich: De Gruyter Oldenbourg, 2021), 189–200.
Thornton is here describing being constipated.
I.e., she had not menstruated for two months.
Thornton here is referring to Wittie's learning and skill as a physician.
This refers to Holy Communion, also known as the Lord's Supper.
This refers to Holy Communion, also known as the Lord's Supper.
See Book 1, 186–90.
See Book 1, 192–3.
I.e., the Devil.
Thornton’s orthography is unclear here.

For Thornton’s marriage settlement, see Book 1, 120-3. On marriage settlements more generally, see Amy Louise Erickson, 'Common Law versus Common Practice: The Use of Marriage Settlements in Early Modern England', The Economic History Review 43, no. 1 (1990): 21–39.

p.hi: This indicates that William Thornton had taken over as executor of Christopher Wandesford's will from Maulger Norton, an original executor.

note.p: William Thornton was involved in a Chancery dispute with Robert Nettleton, from at least 1661, which stemmed from his involvement in the administration of Christopher Wandesford’s will: 'Thornton v. R. Nettleton et al.', C 5/633/108, TNA, London. Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652.
‘My heirs and’ is written in a different ink, in Thornton’s hand, and was probably inserted at some point after the main text had been written.
This phrase is written in the same ink as the above insertion and was probably added at the same time.

While Charles II was not officially restored to the throne until May 1660, November 1659 was when the surviving leaders of the Long Parliament (the so-called 'Presbyterian Knot') had agreed to it. Ronald Hutton, The Restoration: A Political and Religious History of England and Wales, 1658–1667 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1993), 105.

On the Thorntons’ disagreement over the naming of their son see Cordelia Beattie, 'A House Divided: How Did the Thorntons Feel about the Restoration of Charles II?', Alice Thornton’s Books (blog), September 12, 2022, https://thornton.kdl.kcl.ac.uk/posts/blog/2022-09-12-a-house-divided.
A later insertion by Thornton.

For Thornton’s marriage settlement, see Book 1, 120-3. On marriage settlements more generally, see Amy Louise Erickson, 'Common Law versus Common Practice: The Use of Marriage Settlements in Early Modern England', The Economic History Review 43, no. 1 (1990): 21–39.

For Thornton’s marriage settlement, see Book 1, 120-3. On marriage settlements more generally, see Amy Louise Erickson, 'Common Law versus Common Practice: The Use of Marriage Settlements in Early Modern England', The Economic History Review 43, no. 1 (1990): 21–39.
‘As may more appear’ is written in a different ink and appears to have been added at a later date in Thornton’s hand.
See Book 2, 240–4.
I.e., he had fathered a child outside of marriage.

The stigma of illegitimacy was not uniform in England during the early modern period, but Fisher's purported illegitimacy and fathering of a child outside wedlock made him an unsuitable spouse, in Thornton's view. See Richard Adair, Courtship, Illegitimacy and Marriage in Early Modern England (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1996), 89–90.
'Brother' and 'sister' here encompass biological and in-law siblings.

Anti-Scottish sentiment had been ongoing since the later Middle Ages and intensified during the reign of James I, who united both countries. This sentiment continued through the Wars of the Three Kingdoms with many Scottish soldiers fighting for the parliamentarian cause. See Mark Stoyle, Soldiers and Strangers: An Ethnic History of the English Civil War (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005), 75–90.

Anti-Scottish sentiment had been ongoing since the later Middle Ages and intensified during the reign of James I, who united both countries. This sentiment continued through the Wars of the Three Kingdoms with many Scottish soldiers fighting for the parliamentarian cause. See Mark Stoyle, Soldiers and Strangers: An Ethnic History of the English Civil War (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005), 75–90.
Running gout was thought to be caused by humours moving around the body. See Richard Blackmore, Discourses on the Gout, a Rheumatism, and the King’s Evil (London: J. Pemberton, 1726), 115–6.
We have not been able to trace William Thornton in this role so far.
Thornton may have realised her error in that the fright concerning a bond was at East Newton, covered under the next heading (229–36) and that is why the rest of the page is blank (see image).

Thornton's account here gives us a much more accurate date for the building (c.1656–62) than that by Pevsner (1620–30): Jane Grenville and Nikolaus Pevsner, Yorkshire: The North Riding (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2023), 261.
The distance between East Newton Hall and Holy Trinity, Stonegrave is 1.2 miles.

The Thornton family of East Newton can be traced back to at least the fourteenth century. The family established a private chapel at East Newton in 1397. See George R. Keiser, 'Robert Thornton: Gentleman, Reader and Scribe', in Robert Thornton and His Books: Essays on the Lincoln and London Thornton Manuscripts, ed. Susanna Fein and Michael Johnston (Woodbridge: Boydell & Brewer, 2014), 67.

R. Nettleton et al.', C 5/633/108, TNA, London. Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652.

Thornton here means £100, as she states below.

The practicalities of daily life meant that ways had to be found around coverture, which meant that a husband took possession of all his wife's property. The 'law of necessities' (or ‘of agency’), for example, allowed married women to make contracts 'for necessities'. See Joanne Bailey, ‘Favoured or Oppressed? Married Women, Property and “Coverture” in England, 1660–1800’, Continuity and Change 17 (2002), 356–61.
The records of the Chancery case in 1661 state that Nettleton wanted his £500 returned plus damages; he asked for £800. 'Thornton v. R. Nettleton et al.', C 5/633/108, TNA, London.
Thornton discussed her husband being ill-advised on this matter in Book 1, 192–3.
I.e., the new world Thornton had entered, Ryedale.
On dreams in the early modern period see Janine Riviere, Dreams in Early Modern England (Abingdon: Routledge, 2017).

Thornton’s orthography is unclear here but she may mean ‘tourne’ which the OEDO identifies a variant of ‘turn’.

It was not common practice to lock someone in their bedroom during the seventeenth century so perhaps this was due to Thornton’s fear of bailiffs. See also Sasha Handley, Sleep in Early Modern England (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), 140–1.
On dreams in the early modern period see Janine Riviere, Dreams in Early Modern England (Abingdon: Routledge, 2017).

See Book 1, pages 194–7.

In the seventeenth century, the gentry were expected to be – and were regarded as – extremely generous hosts to their neighbours. Thornton felt this was very important in her new neighbourhood. See Felicity Heal, 'The Idea of Hospitality in Early Modern England', Past & Present, no. 102 (1984): 66–93.
I.e., Holy Communion, also known as the Lord's Supper.

In her father's will, Thornton was left £1,500 to be paid at the age of 21 or upon becoming married from the profits of Kirklington, Yarnwicke, and Howgrave (her 'English portion', NLI, Dublin. 'Probate copies of the will of Lord Deputy Christopher Wandesforde; Nos. 196 & 196A,' 2 Oct 1640; copies made Apr 1647 & Dec 1659. Ms 35,458 (1). See also Book 1, 199.
I.e., Thornton would not agree to any more of her husband’s land transactions (until provision for her younger children was sorted).

Below Thornton writes 1656: Book 2, 250. Other information suggests it was summer 1659. [Jo to chk at TNA]

Thornton was left £1,500 in her father’s will to be paid at the age of 21 or upon becoming married from the profits of Kirklington, Yarnwicke, and Howgrave (her 'English portion'. 'Probate copies of the will of Lord Deputy Christopher Wandesforde; Nos. 196 & 196A,' 2 Oct 1640; copies made Apr 1647 & Dec 1659. Ms 35,458 (1), National Library of Ireland, Dublin. See also Book 1, 199.

One William Parkinson described Wandesford's Irish estates being ransacked by rebels: Deposition of William Parkinson, 11/2/1643, 1641 Depositions, Trinity College Dublin, MS 812, fols 190r–192v, https://1641.tcd.ie/index.php/deposition/?depID=812190r162. Accessed 04 December 2023.

William Foxley was Mayor of Hull in 1657-8 and so it is likely that Thornton has made an error with the date as well as his forename: 'List of Mayors and Lord Mayors of Hull, 1331-2019', Hull History Centre, https://hullhistorycentre.org.uk/research/research-guides/PDF/Mayors-and-Lord-Mayors-of-Hull-1331-2019.pdf, accessed 5 February 2024.

Assize week was generally held twice a year in county towns in England and Wales, at Lent (usually in March or April) and Summer (usually in July or August). See 'Civil Court Cases: Assize Courts 1656-1971', The National Archives, https://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/help-with-your-research/research-guides/civil-court-cases-assize-courts-1656-1971/. [if Thorpe and 1659 it was cancelled in lent]

Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652, with a case against Christopher Wandesford, Thornton's brother: 'Nettleton v. C. Wandesford et al.', C 5/379/135, TNA, London. In 1653 and later in 1656 Nettleton was in dispute with Thornton's uncle William Wandesford: 'Nettleton v. W. Wandesford', C 5/402/105, TNA, London; 'Nettleton v. Wandesford', C 22/811/15, TNA, London.
I.e., consent to the sale of this land in which she had an interest.

Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652, with a case against Christopher Wandesford, Thornton's brother: 'Nettleton v. C. Wandesford et al.', C 5/379/135, TNA, London. In 1653 and later in 1656 Nettleton was in dispute with Thornton's uncle William Wandesford: 'Nettleton v. W. Wandesford', C 5/402/105, TNA, London; 'Nettleton v. Wandesford', C 22/811/15, TNA, London.
Between 12 June and 3 September 1656 Thornton had three living children: Alice (Nally), Elizabeth (Betty), and Katherine. [and in July/aug 1659?]

It was customary for married women to be taken aside and questioned separately to confirm they consented willingly. See Sylvia Seeliger, ‘Hampshire Women as Landholders: Common Law Mediated by Manorial Custom.’ Rural History 7, no. 1 (1996): 1–14.
The settlement of Burn Park is described by Thornton in Book 2, 245.
See Book 2, 245.
On gambling on horses, see Mike Huggins, Horse Racing and British Society in the Long Eighteenth Century (Woodbridge: Boydell, 2018), 79–121.

Thornton's 'English portion' was £1,500 to be paid at the age of 21 or upon marriage from the profits of Kirklington, Yarnwicke, and Howgrave. 'Probate copies of the will of Lord Deputy Christopher Wandesforde; Nos. 196 & 196A, 2 Oct 1640; copies made Apr 1647 & Dec 1659', Ms 35,458 (1), National Library of Ireland, Dublin.

Many gentry houses contained a ‘great parlour’ and ‘little parlour’. While the former was used for entertaining guests, the latter tended to have been reserved for the family’s day-to-day eating and drinking. See Nicholas Cooper, Houses of the Gentry, 1480–1680 (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1999), 291–2.

In Alice Wandesford's will the residue of goods not allocated was given to Thornton and her children. See 'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Lord Deputy Wandesford — 10th January 1658. Proved at London 19th July 1660', Hardy Bertram McCall, The Story of the Family of Wandesforde of Kirklington & Castlecomer […] (London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton & co., 1904), 35–8; ‘The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford’, 10 January 1658, PROB 11/298/624, TNA, London.
Thornton refusing to attach her seal effectively rendered the document unauthenticated.
By 1662, the Thorntons had lost four of six children.
See Book 2, 193–5.
Thornton did not miscarry Robert but came very close to doing so when she became ill at Oswaldkirk church in February 1662: Book 2, 193–5.
See Book Rem, 59–60.

William Thornton was involved in a Chancery dispute with Robert Nettleton, from at least 1661, which stemmed from his involvement in the administration of Christopher Wandesford’s will: 'Thornton v. R. Nettleton et al.', C 5/633/108, TNA, London. Nettleton's dispute with the heirs of Christopher Wandesford had been ongoing since 1652.
See Book 2, 231.
On dreams in the early modern period see Janine Riviere, Dreams in Early Modern England (Abingdon: Routledge, 2017).

Women's closets often functioned as private spaces for reading in seventeenth-century England; it is not unremarkable that Thornton kept her stock of salves and ointments in her closet too. See David Pearson, Book Ownership in Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2021), 37–40.

Syrup of cloves was a popular ingredient in early modern England, an aromatic which was added to medical recipes to make them more palatable. Its uses and preparation are described in the 'Edinburgh Pharmacopoeia' of 1699; see the English translation by A. Duncan, The Edinburgh New Dispensatory […] (Edinburgh: Bell and Bradfute, 1810), 265–7, 628–9. The powder, with the medical properties, was possibly dissolved into the syrup to make it drinkable.

note.p: The waters at Scarborough Spa, a healing remedy advised by the family physician, Dr Wittie, who himself wrote a treatise on the virtues of this very spa: Robert Wittie, Scarbrough Spaw […] (London: Charles Tyus, 1660).
I.e., she was not convinced she was pregnant.
I.e., the action of riding had left her sore.

On the hall in early modern England see Catherine Richardson, 'Introducing the Early Modern Parlour', Middling Culture, https://middlingculture.com/2022/04/28/introducing-the-virtual-early-modern-parlour/.
Thornton's Irish portion was £1,000 after one year of marriage from the profits of Castlecomer.
See Book 1, 214–18.
This suggests that Thornton wrote a 'book of meditations' which has not survived alongside her four books.

I.e., ‘haemorrhagist’, the woman who was cured of a bloody issue of 12 years by touching Christ’s garment. The earliest attestation of ‘haemmorhagy’ to mean a flux of blood in OEDO is from c.1400. Do we need a ref here, since we’re just using OEDO?

Comber studied for his MA at Cambridge in 1666 and then went to London for some time as he was not able to take up the rectorship of Stonegrave. The Autobiographies and Letters of Thomas Comber, ed. C. E. Whiting. Surtees Society 156 (Durham: Andrews & Co., 1946), I:6.
Thornton's Irish portion was £1,000 after one year of marriage from the profits of Castlecomer.
This insertion is in Thornton’s hand but in a different ink and presumably stands for Thomas Comber and Alice Thornton, although likely the latter was Thornton’s daughter, also named Alice.
'Settlement of William Thornton, September 19, 1667', CCOM-84, Durham Cathedral Library.

Women who had given birth were advised to stay in bed for at least one month to help with their physical recovery. See Leah Astbury, 'Being Well, Looking Ill: Childbirth and the Return to Health in Seventeenth-Century England', Social History of Medicine 30, no. 3 (2017): 500–19.
Thornton's last child was born on 11 November 1667.

In 1667 Nally was thirteen years old. Legally, girls could marry at fourteen with parental consent. . See Christopher Durston, The Family in the English Revolution, chap. 4; K.J. Kesselring and Tim Stretton, Marriage, Separation and Divorce in England, 1500-1700, chap. 5.

Comber sent verses to Nally in York when she was studying there in 1666. Printed in the appendix of the 1799 edition of his memoirs by his great-grandson are some love verses which may be the same verses he sent to her. Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Thomas Comber, D.D. Sometime Dean of Durham […], ed. Thomas Comber (London: W. J. & J. Richardson, 1799), 42–3, 407.

p.hi: [£ or d – is it a one of payment of £100 and then a rent of 100d or is AT confused? text here keeps switching between 100d and £100, as did Book 3, so we need to sort out which we think it is]

note.p: I.e., the lies that were being spread about Alice Thornton's affair with Thomas Comber.

Thornton names Mary Breakes, Barbara Todd and Anne Danby as the main spreaders of rumours within her household, and Charles Tancred as an external rumourmonger, though there were very likely more. Barbara Todd (later Pape) died in 1675; Mary Breakes (later Heard) might be the Mary Heard (Hurd) buried at Hemingborough in 1691; Anne Danby died in 1695, and Charles Tancred in 1711.
See Book 3, 95.
This deed survives. 'Settlement of William Thornton, September 19, 1667', CCOM-84, Durham Cathedral Library.
